blocks.text: Thousands of arrow headss, spear heads, stone axe exess, tomahawaks and other Indian relics are embedded in various parts of the building in designs of Indian orijiggin.
Old cast iron parts of a stove in a fireplace at the rear of the museum.

blocks.text: The well preserved home of James Buchanan, fifteenth president of the United States (1857–1861) and the only president to come from Pennsylvania. Historians generally call Buchanan's administration weak and vacillating, but local defenders point to Lincoln’s first term as being of the same nature.
October is a month to get out of doors.

pages.full_text:
The well preserved home of James Buchanan, fifteenth president of the United States (1857–1861) and the only president to come from Pennsylvania. Historians generally call Buchanan's administration weak and vacillating, but local defenders point to Lincoln’s first term as being of the same nature.

October is a month to get out of doors.

blocks.text: December 1 – 9, 1951; On a trip for American Business Clubs to western North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia we traverse a section of the Blue Ridge Parkway (see special book on American Business Club for complete account of the trip).
INTERIOR
Kitty and Gordon enter the Parkway near Galax, Va., and within a mile or two cross into North Carolina.

blocks.text: August 15, 1951 - Louise observes her fifth birthday with a party. Guests are Nancy, Cindy, Kathy, David Stoeckel, Hank Verwohl, Billy Robinson, Johnny Far-mer, Tommy Moore, Mary Ann Newswanger. Gordon escorts Louise to dinner at the Stevens House.

pages.full_text: August 15, 1951 - Louise observes her fifth birthday with a party. Guests are Nancy, Cindy, Kathy, David Stoeckel, Hank Verwohl, Billy Robinson, Johnny Far-mer, Tommy Moore, Mary Ann Newswanger. Gordon escorts Louise to dinner at the Stevens House.

blocks.text: Christmas, 1951 - Gordon and Kitty entertain at a buffet dinner for the families. Present were Grandfather and Grandmother Kreider, Grandmother Landreth, Uncle Tom, Kitty's sisters Mary and Esther Weaver, Aunt Esther Buckwalter, Jacob Near, and, of course, the children, Nancy, Cindy, Kathy and Louise.

blocks.text: Early March -- a peaceful scene in northern Lancaster County.

March 28 to April 19, 1952 – Kitty accompanies Gordon on a trip to Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico, Iowa and Illinois for American Business Clubs. 5237 miles.
See special book covering trip in detail.

blocks.text: July, 1952
Nancy directs the children in a neighborhood show. Grandmother Landreth and Kitty are interested spectators. Profit: 16¢ per player.
July 29, 30, 31, 1952 – Sales meeting for Teacher Agents of Educators Mutual Insurance Company held at Skyline Inn in the Poconos.
Uncle John Evans and his family from Deer Lake, Pa. visit Uncle Tom and Grandmother Landreth.

blocks.text: On the return trip from Rehoboth Beach we drive two miles off the main road to Lewes, Del., on Delaware Bay, to see the Zwèeaenendaal Museum, a small scale adaptation of the ancient Town Hall at Hoornr, Holland, which was erected in 1931 to commemorate the 300th Anniversary of the first landing and settlement by the Dutch. (right)
End - trip to shore.
Late August – Members of Lancaster Chapter, National Office Management Association (NOMA), attend an annual picnic near Millersville. (Gordon kneeling second from right.)

Gordon in his office,
Educators Mutual Insurance Company.

blocks.text: FIRST DAY, Saturday, August 30 – Left Lancaster 7:00 A. M. after breakfast; due north through coal region of Pennsylvania; to Bing-hampton, N. Y.; to Utica; into Adirondack Park as far as Long Lake; 379 miles.
"Time out" near Tunkhannock, Pa.
INTERCHANGE

blocks.text: SECOND DAY, Sunday, August 31 – From Long Lake to Tupper Lake for breakfast; to Saranac Lake; to Lake Placid; trip up White-face Mountain; lunch in woods; return to Lake Placid; to Keene for night; early stop at 5:00 P. M.; 111 miles only.

blocks.text: Beeaaauuuutiiifffful Llakakee Pllallalaccid, wwwiiith Whittelfaceface Mountain.
Kitty and Ve.

Twin cabins at Keene, N. Y. are expensive - $13 for four.
$14000 in six months plus expenses on the road and a little more to pay off debts; K Keeeneeenee... New Jersey, New York...
$125 per month is too high for 6 people

blocks.text: THIRD DAY, Monday, September 1 – Through rugged mountains south of Keene; past Schroon Lake; to Amsterdam; rain begins to fall; enter Catskills; to Hancock; cross Delaware River at Narrowsburg; through Poconos; rain ends; to Allentown, Reading and home; 457 miles.
A chained racock at a station where we stop for gas.

pages.full_text:

blocks.text: The children return to school on Wednesday after Labor Day. Nancy is in 8th grade; Cindy in 6th; Kathy in 4th; and Louise in 1st. All four have their hair cut for the occasion...and only Kathy appears displeased.
Consolidated schools rapidly are replacing the one room school in Lancaster County.
Chestnut Level Presbyterian Church on which construction was begun before Rev. War.
Zion's Reformed Church near Brickerville, erected 1813.

blocks.text: A COMPLETE LIST OF THE COVERED BRIDGES OF LANCASTER COUNTY (TO OCTOBER, 1952).
4. Chickies Creek - within sight of Sporting Hill.
5. Cocalico Creek - west of Reading Pike, near Akron.
6. Muddy Creek - near Red Run.
7. Chickies Creek - close to Salunga (near #1).
8. Cocalico Creek - within sight of Reading Road, near Reamstown.
. Middle Creek - north of Millway.

blocks.text:
September, 1951 - A trip to Caledonia State Park; then north through Piney Mountain to Fuller Lake and Laurel Lake; home via Boiling Springs and York.
Left Lancaster at 12 noon -- returned 8:15 P. M.
Total trip - 165 miles.
Stewartstown
The children (above) inspect one of the many cannons; a large white bird (left) is "caught" flying over the now peace-ful battlefield.

Gordon, Kitty, Bill and Ve Huber on a search for cov-
ered bridges in southern Lancaster County.

blocks.text: December 11, 1952 – the new Conestoga Chapter of American Business Clubs is chartered, with Gordon, who served as chairman of the expansion committee, as toastmaster. The first officers and directors of the new club are shown above: (seated) Siegler, Malloy, Bauman, Blank; (standing) Williams, Farmer, Horvath, Hess, Herr, Hess. Seventy two charter members make it the largest ABC Club ever chartered.
A pre-holiday get together at the Hubers' apartment: G Gordon and Kitty, Bill and Ve Huber, Lloyd and Kitty Nolt, John and Peg Hinkle. (Rolleiflex; flash with automatic shutter release.)

blocks.text: Holiday diversions - games in the living room and visits to the movies.
Nancy and Fluffy (the other kitten disappeared without trace several months previously).
End of the year 1958.

blocks.text:
A picnic lunch in Caledonia State Park,
followed by a hike through the woods and wading in a stream by the children.
Louise fell in the water and thereafter was attired in Kitty's jacket.

blocks.text: Some of the covered bridges of Lancaster County which have been torn down in recent years...
The Old Factory Bridge across the Conestoga Creek at the foot of S. Duke Street at Williamson Park was razed about 1948.

blocks.text: Covered bridge over West Octoraro Creek at Spruce Grove, just north of Tayloria, was burned by Halloween pranksters in 1950. In any case, it would have soon been inundated by the reservoir to supply water for the city of Chester, Pa.
Another covered bridge which was lost to the Chester City reservoir. It was located across East Octoraro Creek on a dirt road between Chester and Lancaster counties, north of Route 472.
Today, all that this left of the bridge shown above is this stone approach.

pages.full_text:

Today, all that this left of the bridge shown above is this stone approach.

Fuller Lake and Laurel Lake
Sandwiches to tide us over until we get home - near New Cumberland.
As we approach York the sun sets behind the distant hills (yellow filter; 1/40, f2).
End - trip to Caledonia

blocks.text: Educators Mutual Insurance Company hold its Annual Outing at the Stone Barn near Millersville. Yes, that's Kitty trying to pass a grapefruit under her chin.
Nancy enters Junior High School (7th grade) and is transferred to Neffsville High School.
Louise begins her kindergarten year at the Brecht School.
